block.p: The Economy

In the first swap of emissions allowances, the T.V.A. and Wisconsin Power and Light will announce that they have signed a contract that calls for the T.V.A. to buy the right to emit some sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, freeing it from having to clean up its own plants as stringently. It could break the ice for dozens of similar deals. The price was not disclosed but is believed to be around $2.5 million to $3 million. [ Page A1. ]
The Economy

In the first swap of emissions allowances, the T.V.A. and Wisconsin Power and Light will announce that they have signed a contract that calls for the T.V.A. to buy the right to emit some sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, freeing it from having to clean up its own plants as stringently. It could break the ice for dozens of similar deals. The price was not disclosed but is believed to be around $2.5 million to $3 million. [ Page A1. ]
Seeking to block an increase in the premiums banks pay to the deposit insurance fund, bankers and Administration officials said they were close to victory on the eve of a pivotal vote. [ D1. ]

Investors who bring complaints against brokers cannot be sure of getting a competent and impartial hearing, the G.A.O. concluded, unless improvements are made in the way arbitrators are recruited and trained. [ D1. ]
College graduates are entering one of the toughest job markets that any class has seen in decades. [ A1. ]
The percentage of workers earning less than $12,195 grew sharply in the last decade, a long-delayed U.S. report shows. [ A15. ] Companies

G. Heileman Brewing is introducing a malt liquor similar to Power Master, which it withdrew when regulators said the name emphasized its high alcohol content and advocates complained that the product was aimed at young black men. [ D1. ]
Wal-Mart produced another set of stunning numbers -- profits up 26.1 percent -- as retailers started reporting earnings. [ D5. ]
Hughes Aircraft agreed to acquire General Dynamics' missile business for stock worth at least $450 million. [ D5. ]
Thrifty Rent-a-Car plans to push its personality in a new direction: more fun for both employees and customers. [ D5. ]
Has Oldsmobile's Achieva lived up to its name? The evidence is mixed. [ D5. ]
Scott C. Newquist suddenly left Kidder, Peabody, where he was head of investment banking, because of what he called "differences of management style and philosophy." [ D6. ]
Astra is cutting the price of Foscavir, an eye drug that is one of the most expensive treatments for an AIDS-related disease, for patients in Federal public health programs. [ D6. ]
Ecogen will name James P. Reilly Jr. as its president and chief operating officer. [ D6. ]
Some U.S. wine makers have learned a new word, value, after decades of using mystique, prestige and cachet. [ D1. ]
A judge found a newspaper truck-drivers' union in contempt of court for disrupting circulation of The New York Times. [ B1. ] International
In Japan, a powerful sense of anxiety underlies the thinking of most business executives these days. [ D1. ] Markets
Blue-chip stocks rose to record highs, propelled by optimism that the Fed will lower interest rates another notch. The Dow gained 28.17, to 3,397.58. [ D1. ]
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in quiet action, as traders awaited other economic data. [ D19. ]
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet dealings. Gold prices were mixed. [ D20. ]
Prices for grain and soybeans sank after rainfall in Kansas and forecasts of more. [ D20. ] Today's Columns
I.B.M. is asking its employees to pay a bit more of their hospital costs. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [ D2. ]
Pacific Telesis, not wanting to be seen as another boring utility, is studying whether to split itself in two. Market Place. [ D10. ]
Warner Brothers' ad campaign for "Lethal Weapon 3" helps explain why studios love sequels. Advertising. [ D23. ]
